summary: Esther Dot's answer to How do you feel about no one finding love in the series finale of Game of Thrones? - Quora
title: Esther Dot's answer to How do you feel about no one finding love in the series finale of Game of Thrones? - Quora
description:
The real issue is that not only do the romantic pairings almost all end, but nearly every deep emotional bond is severed or abandoned as well. The surviving characters with the closest relationships all leave each other and go their separate ways. That combined with the death of at least half of each couple moves us from incidental territory into the purposeful destruction of nearly all the significant relationships. Think about that montage of Jon, Sansa, and Arya at the end. Sure, there are people around them, but they are alone.

You aren’t exaggerating when you say no one finds love, because ultimately, it appears no one has romantic or familial love. Not only does romantic love die figuratively and literally, none of the Starks remain together. Bran is emotionally disconnected from his family in s7, and that doesn’t change in s8. Arya and Sansa respect each other, but we don’t even get a good bonding scene or goodbye between them. Jon and Sansa have a deep emotional connection, but a portion of the fandom doesn’t like Sansa, so they’re convinced that Jon not verbally forgiving Sansa means he didn’t. Jon and Arya have the strongest family bond, but what happens in their last scene? Jon invites Arya to come visit him and she says, “I’d rather risk death exploring instead.” Pretty sure that’s an exact quote.

Now, I talk Jon’s character arc here

Esther Dot’s answer to What is your review of the Game of Thrones character ‘Jon Snow’?

and I argue that it is his love for the Starks that overrides his duty to his queen, and while I think that’s a valid interpretation because it makes sense of his character arc, it is (verbally) unconfirmed by the show. So, apparently the Stark family is relegated to “duty” which leaves us with what? Brienne in a council meeting listening to Tyrion and Bronn and their obsession with brothels, Bran stuck in his visions, Arya leaving all her family behind, Sansa alone without a single familiar face in her coronation scene, and Jon, poor Jon is back to where he had been condemned to go by his bastard status, cut off from the only family and home he knew.

As much as we throw around the descriptors of realistic, violent, grim, this ending descends into pointlessly painful. It’s one thing to have a story discuss despair, it’s another to have a show present the idea that there is no end but a bad one. D&D, without acknowledging it, are presenting an ending in which, as much as characters try, they will never love or be loved because even if they momentarily stumble across something good, it ends in death. If you accept the general perception of the finale than this is truest for Jon who has had two women he loved die in his arms. And then they throw Ghost at our heads to distract us.

This isn’t upsetting because it isn’t what we wanted for the characters, this is wrong because the show has told us the opposite for so long. For season after season, character after character, we have been told that the bond of family overrides oaths and loyalty. This should have been showcased between the Starks this season because it would have given us some sense of hope for the future, but instead, the familial bond that is highlighted is between Jaime and Tyrion. Why? Because that relationship ends in death too. Are you sensing a pattern?

For our romantic couples, the only one left standing is Sam/Gilly. They’re going to have a child, but he’s a Maester now? And technically they’re supposed to be celibate? So, while I assume Bran didn’t mind, will allow it, even that ending has me scratching my head and a little worried.

As for the couples that bit the dust this season alone:

Grey Worm/Missandei

Jaime/Brienne

Euron/Cersei (I feel like that doesn’t really count but they had sex so whatever)

Jaime/Cersei (bonus points for both dying!)

Jorah/Dany (kinda. Wait, they both died too!)

Jon/Dany

Gendry/Arya (They’re the winners of the losers because they’re both still alive!)

What’s extra strange about this is that for two of these couples, there’s a rush to have them have sex right before their relationship ends. Apparently, the Arya/Gendry and Brienne/Jaime hookups solely exist to make Jaime returning to Cersei more upsetting, and Arya leaving Westeros…an informed decision? Sorry Gendry, for Arya, whatever you were offering was just not worth sticking around for. Make of that what you will.

It’s a deliberate decision on the creators’ part to bring these couples together only to emphatically tear them apart. There’s a viciousness to this that moves us away from tragic and pushes us towards cruel. To top it off, what some people thought was the epic romance of the series ends with Jon stabbing Dany in the heart. The show tries to tell you that Dany is now the embodiment of evil and love and that Jon must kill her. I never believed that Jon loved Dany, but if you did, the climactic moment of the season, of the whole series, is the death of love.

D&D ruthlessly destroyed one relationship after another, and while that might make us unhappy, it isn’t consistent with the world they created either. The show has told us how important children are to the future, that they are why characters live and fight and that they are the means of creating political stability as well. To use one episode to undermine all of that, to pretend like they can upend how things have always been, everything they have been telling us with one scene, is laughable. Romantic, or at least, sexual relationships matter in GoT because of what it means for the future, good or bad. The future can only exist, the audience can only have hope, if we see the relationships that will provide it and secure it. And what does the finale give us? The death of all such relationships, the death of love. What do we get instead? Grass. They murdered love and therefore hope and thought some melting snow and vegetation was a decent substitution.

It’s nonsensical and insulting to act like the end of so many great houses, including the Starks (8x04 is titled “The Last of the Starks”) isn’t without ramifications, isn’t going to lead to chaos, isn’t a tragedy. This all goes unacknowledged. The show doesn’t adequately address the pervasive sense of isolation in the finale, and this makes the ending not matter because they didn’t situate it in a coherent emotional context, contradicting ideas that have been integral to GoT since episode one.

Love, whether familial or romantic, has been essential to the story and characters in season after season of the show. Jon’s existence is due to Ned’s love for his sister, he commits treason for love of his nephew. Catelyn Stark grabs the blade of a knife with her bare hands to save Bran. Robb goes to war for his father. Jon risks death when he attempts to leave the Night’s Watch to join him. Sansa begs for Ned’s life on her knees. You get the idea. We have countless examples telling us that love motivates these characters, that love is essential, that love matters. Love, relationships, have been the core of GoT until halfway through 8x06 when they try to flip the script on us. I don’t want to give the creators credit for being deliberately nihilistic. I don’t think they even knew what they were communicating.

This death of love idea/lack of romantic relationships doesn’t work. It doesn’t work for the story, it doesn’t work for the characters, it doesn’t work in the world they created. All of it could have been done in a manner that worked, but none of it was. There are a dozen different ways to argue that the universal failure of relationships in the last season of GoT is a mistake, none of which are about my feelings. But speaking of those, I hated that every relationship ended in varying degrees of pain, sadness, abandonment, or death. And inexplicably, a blade of grass doesn’t make me feel better about it.

Jon/Dany

Gendry/Arya (They’re the winners of the losers because they’re both still alive!)

What’s extra strange about this is that for two of these couples, there’s a rush to have them have sex right before their relationship ends. Apparently, the Arya/Gendry and Brienne/Jaime hookups solely exist to make Jaime returning to Cersei more upsetting, and Arya leaving Westeros…an informed decision? Sorry Gendry, for Arya, whatever you were offering was just not worth sticking around for. Make of that what you will.

It’s a deliberate decision on the creators’ part to bring these couples together only to emphatically tear them apart. There’s a viciousness to this that moves us away from tragic and pushes us towards cruel. To top it off, what some people thought was the epic romance of the series ends with Jon stabbing Dany in the heart. The show tries to tell you that Dany is now the embodiment of evil and love and that Jon must kill her. I never believed that Jon loved Dany, but if you did, the climactic moment of the season, of the whole series, is the death of love.

D&D ruthlessly destroyed one relationship after another, and while that might make us unhappy, it isn’t consistent with the world they created either. The show has told us how important children are to the future, that they are why characters live and fight and that they are the means of creating political stability as well. To use one episode to undermine all of that, to pretend like they can upend how things have always been, everything they have been telling us with one scene, is laughable. Romantic, or at least, sexual relationships matter in GoT because of what it means for the future, good or bad. The future can only exist, the audience can only have hope, if we see the relationships that will provide it and secure it. And what does the finale give us? The death of all such relationships, the death of love. What do we get instead? Grass. They murdered love and therefore hope and thought some melting snow and vegetation was a decent substitution.

It’s nonsensical and insulting to act like the end of so many great houses, including the Starks (8x04 is titled “The Last of the Starks”) isn’t without ramifications, isn’t going to lead to chaos, isn’t a tragedy. This all goes unacknowledged. The show doesn’t adequately address the pervasive sense of isolation in the finale, and this makes the ending not matter because they didn’t situate it in a coherent emotional context, contradicting ideas that have been integral to GoT since episode one.

Love, whether familial or romantic, has been essential to the story and characters in season after season of the show. Jon’s existence is due to Ned’s love for his sister, he commits treason for love of his nephew. Catelyn Stark grabs the blade of a knife with her bare hands to save Bran. Robb goes to war for his father. Jon risks death when he attempts to leave the Night’s Watch to join him. Sansa begs for Ned’s life on her knees. You get the idea. We have countless examples telling us that love motivates these characters, that love is essential, that love matters. Love, relationships, have been the core of GoT until halfway through 8x06 when they try to flip the script on us. I don’t want to give the creators credit for being deliberately nihilistic. I don’t think they even knew what they were communicating.

This death of love idea/lack of romantic relationships doesn’t work. It doesn’t work for the story, it doesn’t work for the characters, it doesn’t work in the world they created. All of it could have been done in a manner that worked, but none of it was. There are a dozen different ways to argue that the universal failure of relationships in the last season of GoT is a mistake, none of which are about my feelings. But speaking of those, I hated that every relationship ended in varying degrees of pain, sadness, abandonment, or death. And inexplicably, a blade of grass doesn’t make me feel better about it.
trail.content_abstract:
The real issue is that not only do the romantic pairings almost all end, but nearly every deep emotional bond is severed or abandoned as well. The surviving characters with the closest relationships all leave each other and go their separate ways. That combined with the death of at least half of each couple moves us from incidental territory into the purposeful destruction of nearly all the significant relationships. Think about that montage of Jon, Sansa, and Arya at the end. Sure, there are people around them, but they are alone.

You aren’t exaggerating when you say no one finds love, because ultimately, it appears no one has romantic or familial love. Not only does romantic love die figuratively and literally, none of the Starks remain together. Bran is emotionally disconnected from his family in s7, and that doesn’t change in s8. Arya and Sansa respect each other, but we don’t even get a good bonding scene or goodbye between them. Jon and Sansa have a deep emotional connection, but a portion of the fandom doesn’t like Sansa, so they’re convinced that Jon not verbally forgiving Sansa means he didn’t. Jon and Arya have the strongest family bond, but what happens in their last scene? Jon invites Arya to come visit him and she says, “I’d rather risk death exploring instead.” Pretty sure that’s an exact quote.
